comments.author: INTELIGENCIA89

comments.text:
+GameXplain Even though I still don't "agree" with this new system, I do 
"respect" your decision regardless and won't talk about it anymore. ^_^

But, just to give you guys an example of why I prefer numbers over a 
certain "phrase" to judge a game, recently, I was 50/50 in terms of buying 
Sonic Lost World for 3DS or not. In fact, even when I was listening to your 
video review about the game, I STILL wasn't sure if I wanted to buy it or 
not. However, the moment when Derrick gave the game 3 out of 5 stars, THAT 
was the moment when I said "ok, I'm not buying this game". If Derrick 
instead used a random "phrase" as a rating at the end of that video, I am 
100% sure that I "wouldn't" have made that decision and still would have 
remained confused/unsure if I want to buy the game or not afterwards.

So yeah "numbers" do matter FOR ME at least and are equally important for 
me as much as the review itself to make up my mind about buying a game or 
not at the end.

My preference. My opinion.

P.S: Good job GameXplain as always! :)
comments.author: Infinity Master

comments.text: +INTELIGENCIA89 "Like" ~ Derrick
comments.author: GameXplain

comments.text:
+GameXplain How would you (Derrick) rate Yoshi's New Island using this new 
system?
comments.author: INTELIGENCIA89

comments.text:
+Infinity Master I totally hear you; this is new to us too, but we did put 
a lot of thought into it. I honestly think scores offer the illusion of 
accuracy, and that's even more the case the more numbers that you have to 
work with (like a 100-point scale).

We really do believe this new system offers a lot more clarity. Whereas, as 
an example, if we gave a game 3.5 / 5 before, what exactly does that mean? 
But if we said we "Liked" it (as only an example), we feel that it 
instantly conveys how we felt.

But I really do appreciate your comments and that you're keeping an 
open-mind about it. And hey, you can still get your score from pretty much 
every other review outlet out there =D
comments.author: GameXplain

comments.text:
+Infinity Master Using a standard rating system is the less accurate way. 
Proclaiming that a game is universally this amount of good is stupid. What 
about games in different genres? Different playstyles? Different moods and 
tones? Focuses on story vs. gameplay? How do you compare all of those 
games? And what is the difference in feeling between an 8 and a 9? Did the 
enjoyment factor go up a certain universal percent between the numbers? All 
it does is cause arguments. Summing up the general experience the reviewer 
had over using a scoring system better shows how much enjoyment the 
reviewer had.
comments.author: SashaandStorm

comments.text:
+GameXplain Fine, but the problem with this new system is that there are 
"millions" of "phrases" that can be used to express an opinion on a game, 
which thus will lead to "less accurate" demonstration of how the reviewer 
feels about the game.

On the other hand, in the stars rating system, the end result is gonna be 
summed on a scale of 10 (or 5) and can NEVER be more or less than that, so 
unlike this "expression" system, when narrowing the opinion to a scale of 5 
or 10, that will give a "more accurate" view of how the reviewer feels 
about the game instead of choosing one of million phrases to express his 
opinion (which ALSO can vary from person to person, making it even "less 
accurate" of a review than what it is already).

I'm not complaining, just stating my opinion/concern and whatever you guys 
decide to go with at the end, I'm ok with.
comments.author: Infinity Master

comments.text: +Reaperscreepers Agreed. Glad to see that people understand this.
comments.author: SashaandStorm

comments.text:
+Infinity Master I strongly disagree, The "star rating system" (x/5) or 
even the actual standard (x/10) is far from being accurate and is actually 
very misleading. This "random phrase" is more fitting due to the fact that 
it gives a spectrum in which a game should be considered, which will, in 
fact, be more useful because it invites the reader/spectator to actually 
watch/read the actual review rather than paying more attention to the final 
score.

That's how it should be in my opinion, people should actually read/watch 
the actual pros and cons and make a conclusion by themselves.
comments.author: Reaperscreepers

comments.text:
+Infinity Master "Also, "loved it" is a very subjective word and can VARY 
from person to person "

That's EXACTLY why we're using it. Our reviews have always been 100% 
entirely subjective (as it's impossible to be anything but, even if some 
people try) and now we're wearing that fact on our sleeves. Our opinion 
reflects only our own, and the best we can hope is to explain why we feel 
the way that we do, so that you can determine if you might feel similarly.

I don't feel "Love it" is ambiguous at all; it tells you *exactly* how 
Derrick feels. He Loved it.
comments.author: GameXplain

comments.text:
+Infinity Master I find it odd that you point out that saying "loved it" is 
subjective when the same can be said for a star or number score. Rating 
systems in general are broken. Just focus on the review itself. That's how 
you should find out if a game is worth it, by deciding based on what you 
take from the review.
comments.author: SashaandStorm

comments.text:
+Reaperscreepers Disagree. The stars rating system is the STANDARD way of 
rating games in any gaming channel/website.

Besides, what if Derrick "didn't" like the game very much, what will he 
say? Meh? Kinda loved it? Ok? And then, how will you be able to tell if the 
game is worth buying or not?!

Also, "loved it" is a very subjective word and can VARY from person to 
person (i.e. loved it for one person can mean 10/10 while another 
person might be 8 or 9/10 with "Really loved it" being 10/10). This new 
system is very vague and can be misleading to viewers.

On the other hand, in the "star rating system", it is very much CLEAR in 
terms of how a person feels about a game when he gives it 8 or 9 or 10/10. 
That is a more clear/non-misleading system which I prefer whenever I look 
for a game review and will give me a more "accurate" measure of how the 
reviewer feels about the game rather than a random "phrase" to express his 
opinion about the game.

My opinion.
comments.author: Infinity Master

comments.text:
+Infinity Master I for one think getting away from the very flawed rating 
score is quite good. X/10 is equally as subjective as "loved it".
comments.author: Reaperscreepers

comments.text:

comments.text:
The reason I prefer the Five star system is because I can usually guess the 
rating before the end of a review meaning that I have an idea how the 
reviewer experienced the game. And that's the important part, the actual 
review not the score. When viewers walk away only remembering the score 
than the reviewer didn't do a good job, or the viewer is missing the point. 
I think a lot of websites put too much emphasis on smaller numbers that at 
the end of the day don't mean anything. And people will debate over the 
score instead of the game itself. I think a more simple scoring system 
leaves more room for talking about the games and remembering what the 
reviewers say about games. Instead of arguing that some game is a 7.5  or a 
7. The 1/10 system is fine too, but once decimals are thrown in I can't

I got this game, along with an NES 3DS XL yesterday, and I love it to

being easy and being beat really quickly, is that you still want to pick it 
up and play it more even after you already beat it, not to find ways to 
rack up points or anything, just to see the fun level designs that make 
Kirby games such an enjoyment.

second mode simply for the fact I can buy Smash for the same system as this 
game. And King DeDeDe's Drum Dash, while unique for sure, just doesn't look 
fun at all.

fun. Not doing anything crazy, just fun.﻿

It's the easiest Kirby game for sure. I never had a lick of trouble with 
it. The Kirby franchise is suppose to be entry level but most Kirby games 
offer challenges in the form of True Arena or other unlockable 
modes/collectibles. Epic Yarn had some collectibles but nothing hard to get 
honestly. The game is a peaceful walk. Not saying that's bad but as a long 
time Kirby fan since Dreamland on the gameboy, it's definitely my least 
favorite Kirby game. Very basic and with less moves to experiment with than 
other Kirby games. Even as a non traditional title, other games like Canvas 
Curse and Mass Attack, beat it gameplay-wise. It's a solid entry level 
platformer but stating it's the easiest Kirby game is just a fact. It's not 
an insult against it or anything. Kirby games were never entirely brutal 
(at least not usually their main mode). The point of the franchise it to be 
fun and beatable.

comments.text:
Eh, I think difficulty can be an option or unlocked as it has been in 
recent games but the Kirby franchise should never be made harder. It is an 
Entry Level series famous for it's welcoming gameplay. It fills in a gap 
that no other game was willing to fill at the time of it's creation. Making 
Kirby hard would kind of destroy what makes Kirby.... well Kirby. I have 
nothing against them adding EX mode you can play from the beginning or more 
stuff like the challenging True Arenas... but to make the Kirby games 
themselves, Hard would be bad imo. I think it'd be fine if it was a bit 
more challenging but still welcoming to the long time fans who have enjoyed 
it's ease and for the new comers who need this stepping stone. They can 
always add a hard mode too. That would be fine.

top_comment.text:
I think you guys should give a bit more credit to Kirby's super abilities 
in Return to Dreamland.  There were 5 of them in all: Ultra Sword, Ultra 
Flame, Ultra Snow, Ultra Beam and Ultra Hammer.  You didn't press anything 
with snow and actually had full control of it as you shook the wii remote 
to get it moving.  Also, you controlled the beam the entire time as well 
with the control pad.  Even hammer had strategy when choosing with what 
strength you wanted or in some cases needed to hit something with.  The 
other two are admittedly pushing a button and watching an animation, but 
they were given to you in the first world for a reason.  That being said I 
find the gimmicks in both of these games comparable.  Kirby Triple Deluxe 
will have to be my favorite Kirby game ever if it wants to beat out Kirby's 
Return to Dreamland for my top spot though.﻿

top_comment.author: sazhuy

comments.text:
There is the notion of how a game feels. Adding in colors made those powers 
seem unique. It would cause no time to add it into game play because all it 
is would be a color swap of Kirby. There is more to a game then just it's 
mechanics or knockoffs would run rampant because the feel would mean 
nothing.

Helpers wouldn't be down played in those games. It was a feature that could 
add in multi-player elements to the main game. There are people who like to 
co-op games. That was an amazing feature for it since you could use another 
controller or console to do it.

Just because something is experimental doesn't mean it can not bring good 
elements that were used before. That is the reason to experiment is to find 
out what works so you can implement them again in later titles. No point in 
always forgetting what was good.

Even if that isn't what you want that doesn't mean it isn't what others 
want. It is something I miss but it isn't like I am not going to stop 
playing the games but it removes something I would love to see again as it 
makes the game to me feel more alive and inviting.
comments.author: sazhuy

comments.text:
Changing the ability designs from one game-mode just seems like a waste of 
time and would probably just create visual confusion as well as unnecessary 
contradictions.Why would they spend time developing extra gameplay 
mechanics on top of the new ones they're trying to add? All it does is 
clutter gameplay. There are less then 10 abilities that change Kirby's 
color anyway so it's just not justifiable to spend time on something so 
inconsequential. And really the same could be said for helpers. Why would 
they spend time designing and programming helpers for all the new abilities 
when helpers are the main gameplay quirk of SS and SSU? All it would do is

captions.text:
Kirby has always been one of the more experimental
Nintendo franchises. It's actually quite fitting

considering his adaptive nature. He changes
up his gameplay so much that platformers in

same vein as his original games are actually
less frequent anymore. But Nintendo seems

to be making a conscious effort to bring Kirby
back to his roots while still providing the

fresh gameplay that he's known for. And while
Return to Dreamland captured some of that

old magic, Kirby Triple Deluxe for the 3DS
is bursting with it.

Like all Kirby games, the story is simple
enough. One night after a day of play, a mysterious

beanstalk lifts Kirby's house high into the
sky. When he goes to investigate, he discovers

that King Dedede's castle was also taken by
the beanstalk. Dedede is soon attacked and

captured by a mysterious creature called Taranza.
It's Kirby's mission to travel through six

floating islands and rescue Dedede. The story
does its job in giving Kirby a purpose to

explore a new world and quickly disappears
into the background once the gameplay begins.

However, toward the end of the game, it is
fleshed out a bit more and given some humorous

twists and turns. It's nothing major, but
it is fun to see the interactions between

all of these characters.
But it's the gameplay where Triple Deluxe

really shines. In many ways, it plays just
like past Kirby platformers. He can run, jump,

float, suck up enemies to steal their unique
powers, and use those powers to take on other

enemies and bosses. But where it becomes unique
is in the way it handles the background and

foreground. Kirby can switch between the two
planes by using the new 3D Warpstars. Ones

with an orange center will allow him to go
back and forth while a yellow center means

that there's no coming back. While the concept
has been seen before, most notably in Donkey

Kong Country Returns, Triple Deluxe makes
it almost integral to progression. The background

is almost constantly interacting with the
foreground and vice versa whether it's from

falling objects, enemy attacks, or even solving
puzzles. This actually grants the game a strange

sense of feeling three dimensional even though
Kirby is stuck to a 2D plane at all times.

Kirby has always been about simple platforming
and that holds true here. The game isn't any

more difficult than past games, and while
those could become a little dull because of

that, I never felt bored in Triple Deluxe.
The level design is absolutely superb in the

ways that it plays with the different planes
and, in turn, giving Kirby something new to

do. This could range from dodging a tank firing
on him from the background to using a laser

pole to destroy things in the background and
clear a way forward. Bosses and mini-bosses

also use this new depth to great effect. Almost
every one of them uses the planes in some

way so even old favorites feel different from
before. Like Kirby Super Star and Return to

Dreamland, each ability has multiple moves
that can be used. Though it's fun to use these

moves on regular enemies, it's the bosses
where they become truly useful.

The other new element to Triple Deluxe is
the new Hypernova ability, which greatly improves

Kirby's suction powers to the point where
almost anything is edible. Its power is comparable

to the super abilities in Return to Dreamland,
but it is so much better than those. The super

abilities looked impressive but nothing was
ever done with them. Instead, it was always

walk forward, hit the button, watch the animation,
and repeat. With Hypernova, more thought is

required. Puzzles will often be laid out ahead
of you and while they're nothing too difficult,

they help break up the gameplay and make Hypernova
feel special. And while regular enemies are

quickly taken care of, larger ones are introduced
that require a little more thought. It strikes

an excellent balance between making the player
feel powerful while still providing a challenge.

The story mode in Triple Deluxe isn't too
long and will likely take most players around

seven to ten hours to complete. But the game
is far from over at that point. Right away

Kirby Fighters and Dedede's Drum Dash are
available to play. Kirby Fighters is exactly

what it says, a fighting game featuring ten
of Kirby's iconic powers. You can either go

through a series of progressively harder rounds
in a single player mode or challenge up to

three of your friends in download-play multiplayer.
The mode itself is a kind of cross between

Smash Bros. and a typical fighting game. Each
of the seven stages is directly pulled from

past Kirby games while food and items appear
to help players. The range of abilities is

quite good though there were a few omitted
that I would have liked to seen like Spear.

Overall, it's a fun and chaotic mode that's
at its best when playing with friends though

I'm not sure how long it will hold interest.
The same could be said of Dedede's Drum Dash,

which is a music-based mini-game that has
the titular king jumping across drums to the

beat of four different songs. As he jumps
across, he collects discs for points and is

scored when completing the song. What's somewhat
odd is that matching what the song is doing

is not completely necessary. A perfect run
will complement the music, but a good score

can be achieved even without doing this. There
is a bit of a learning curve to it, but with

only four songs available, it never held my
interest after getting a gold ranking in each

song. However, both Kirby Fighters and Drum
Dash support Street Pass so players can compare

their scores with their friends.
These aren't the only modes in the game as

there are three others that can be unlocked.
These games are where most players will likely

spend their post-game since they can be very
challenging. I won't spoil them here, but

I will say that even though I've been constantly
playing Triple Deluxe for more than a week

and a half, I still haven't achieved 100%.
But these unlockable modes are the most fun

I had outside the main game. In addition to
the extra modes, players can collect keychains

that show off over 250 characters from throughout
Kirby's history. Though they don't unlock

anything on their own, they can be quite addictive
for completionists.

Otherwise, the game simply looks great. It
has a style similar to Return to Dreamland

but softer and more expressive. A ton of Kirby's
personality comes through in this game, especially

during the Hypernova sequences, and even Kirby's
enemies are fun to watch. The 3D is also impressive

and truly enhances the gameplay. But the true
star of this game's presentation is the music.

Kirby games have always had wonderful soundtracks,
and this one's no exception. It has a perfect

balance of remixed classics as well as some
truly awesome new tracks. This may be some

of my favorite Kirby music ever. If you have
headphones, I highly recommend using them.

Kirby Triple Deluxe is an exceptional platformer
that truly captures what makes the pink puffball

so great. While it may lack challenge at first,
the level design is so good and the gameplay

is so fun that it never really mattered to
me. When the challenge did arrive, I enjoyed

it even more. To put it simply, I love it.
Its story mode is charming, and its extra

modes and collectibles provide plenty to do.
Thanks for watching and be sure to stay tuned

to GameXplain for more on Kirby and other
things gaming too.
